text: hi everyone sweet thingy face tano here
the internet's busiest music nerd and
it's time for a review of this new zola
jesus album archon zola jesus aka nika
rosa danilova she is back with her sixth
full-length lp which really builds on
the instrumental ambitions of her last
album now bringing producer randall dunn
into the mix along with a lot of live
drumming from matt chamberlain which
really enhances the percussive side of
the record the result here is zola
jesus's largest sounding album yet and
that's saying something being an artist
who has inhabited dark wave and art pop
spaces for about a decade now zola jesus
is no stranger to toying with space and
atmosphere in her music she even
progressed to a point where her sound
had become pretty enveloping on 2017's
okovi and that's even more so the case
for this new lp and you'll hear it right
away as you dip your toe into the opener
lost which features these ritualistic
mesmerizing drums cycling chants calling
away in the background frigid sheets of
reverb caked all over zola's lead vocals
the whole thing sounds like slowly
making your way down into the cavernous
structures that are pictured on the
album cover here now there are some
points where the size of these songs and
the effects laid into them almost get in
the way of their enjoyability like with
all the buzzing and distorted vocal
effects on the fall for example which i
think are kind of a disservice to nico's
voice i much prefer hearing it in the
raw on the track desire later on the
record which is one of the most stunning
moments on the lp for its simplicity not
that there aren't highlights on this
thing that are on the dense side there
are sone is definitely one it's a rager
in fact with driving drums and bass
topped by zola's vocals that are calling
out into an endless abyss the whole
track undergoes this intense linear
build and progression layering up with
more bass percussion and noise until the
whole track essentially turns into a
frightening drone it's a great moment on
the album but most of these tracks are
content to let the space surrounding
them breathe sometimes in a way that's
mystifying like on the track into the
wild which has some of the most powerful
transition points of any track here with
these rapid synth arpeggios layering
over each other glossy patches some
elastic bass tones that kind of stretch
from one part of the song to another
it's pure ecstasy and zola does a great
job of creating this incredible sonic
contrast between the verses and choruses
on this track too so yeah again great
use of the space surrounding this song
but some tracks on here are so spacious
they feel like they're almost missing
something the song undertow for example
with its heavy drumming and droning
synths which do match perfectly with the
imagery of diving into a deep dark body
of water depicted in the lyrics but i
think the last third of the song really
fails to bring the track to a memorable
finale and the finish of dead and gone
feels even more inconclusive with all of
its suspended orchestrations left
droning in the tracks final moments
though i suppose the track does
effectively create a lull before the
very thunderous zone and i do also like
how this track muse is about
love memories some kind of connection
and whether or not it will outlast like
the death and demise of everything kind
of a powerful sentiment in our current
times where everything seems so
finite the final leg of this lp has some
decent highlights too there is fault
which lyrically is a pretty simple
moment on the album all about choosing
solitude and loneliness and how
zola's choice and that is not uh your
fault the person who she's directing
this message to and that sentiment is
driven in with a lot of repetition and
this really immense build that moves in
a couple of waves in the second half
there's also ephemera which i think is
kind of a moment of fun if you could
call it that sure it's dark and spacious
like nearly every other track on this
record but simultaneously it feels kind
of like a cathartic jam too with all its
howling chants hand drums and what
sounds like maybe even a creaky cello
screaming for dear life either way it's
entrancing in one of the most visceral
moments on the record but then there's
the closer which i have my reservations
with it is
warm harmonically and sonically much
warmer than nearly every other track
here and that does kind of give us a
positive note to to leave on but by that
same token the vocals are more buried
here than they are anywhere else on the
record they seem almost like
disconnected from the progression of the
instrumental in some ways as far as the
melodic progression of the track overall
it just feels a little disjointed just
something about the instrumental and the
vocals that doesn't feel like it's quite
connecting so yeah i'm not entirely
crazy about the finisher but i still
found this record to be pretty solid
overall handily zology's biggest album
to date
but it's also a little maybe too big
sometimes so big that the sounds of
these songs sound bigger than the songs
themselves or the vocals which i think
could have used a bit more focus on the
record could have gotten louder
placement more presence still the vast
majority of the time the melodies and
ideas and lyrics presented on these
tracks are big enough to you know
contend with the size of these songs
sonically they do work hand in hand with
the boundless atmospheres that these
tracks play with and for the most part
we get a very mountainous art pop and
dark wave record i'm feeling a light to
decent seven on this one tran position
have you given this album a listen did
you love it did you hate it what would
you rate it you're the best to the best
what should i review next hit the like
if you like please subscribe and please
don't cry hit the bell as well over here
next to my head it's another video that
you can check out hit that up or the
link to subscribe to the channel uh
anthony fantano zola jesus overever
